Hence!  Paly Sickness haste!</br>Let Pestilence its horrors wing away</br>Far from the roseate day,</br>O'er sterile plains and solitary waste!</br>Let ATROPHY no more</br>With yellow visage boast her noxious reign,</br>Nor sad tormenting pain,</br>Nor dread MARASMUS, with his wither'd cheek,</br>Sure loit'ring vengeance wreak,</br>But all from hence retreat, to trace some sickly shore!

HEALTH, to thee my lyre I string,</br>Mistress of the rosy ring!</br>Straight a floral wreath prepare,</br>For the Goddess blithe and fair!</br>See the featly-footed Queen</br>Sporting on the daisied green;</br>She, whose blushing cheeks disclose</br>All the beauties of the rose.</br>Say, Queen, if in some pathless dell</br>Or pearly grot thou'rt wont to dwell,</br>Near where the stream pellucid flows</br>In gentle tinklings as it goes;</br>Where shady trees extend their arms,</br>And Nature, drest in all her charms,</br>Rose-lipp'd Goddess, ever reigns</br>Smiling o'er the fertile plains?</br>Say, when morning 'gins to dawn,</br>Weeping o'er the primrose lawn;</br>When AURORA ever bright</br>Unbars the golden gates of light,</br>And as a bride-maid leads the day</br>Deck'd in saffron vesture gay;</br>When the lark with mounting wings</br>His much-lov'd early ditty sings;</br>When the cock with clarion shrill</br>Wakes alert each distant hill,</br>Do'st thou the jasmine alcove seek,</br>Diffusing o'er thy beauteous cheek</br>Every bright transcendent hue</br>That e'er the spring's rich garden knew?</br>Or on the verdant carpet spread</br>A fillet for thy florid head,</br>Compos'd of ev'ry scented flow'r</br>That e'er receiv'd the spangled show'r;</br>Carnations sweet and lilies fair,</br>Moss roses cull'd with nicest care,</br>With vi'lets, amaranth, and pink,</br>And daff'dil from the riv'let's brink?</br>Or dost thou, Queen, with pleasure lave</br>Thy iv'ry form in silver wave,</br>While the Naiads chaunt the song,</br>"Mirth and joy to thee belong,"</br>And hail thee Goddess of the plain,</br>Sister of the agile train,</br>Ever comely, ever gay,</br>Mistress of the roundelay!</br>Oh!  Let me trace thee to the grove</br>Where turtles coo their themes of love;</br>Where breathes the soft refrig'rant breeze</br>O'er the glade and through the trees;</br>Where sweet the mellow pipe is heard,</br>And every joyous warb'ling bird</br>Heedless hops from bough to bough,</br>While the peasant drives the plough,</br>Whistling as the glebe he breaks,</br>As his morning toil he takes;</br>Where beneath the umbrose oak</br>Which never felt the woodman's stroke,</br>Nymphs resort to greet their swains,</br>Sigh their loves and tell their pains.</br>There I'd join the light-heel'd throng</br>Who briskly trip the meads along:</br>MIRTH, with rosy-blooming face,</br>Shall be the first to lead the chase;</br>And loose-rob'd FANCY, queen of pleasure,</br>Shall chaunt her most admired measure,</br>Chaunt with never-ceasing glee</br>Strains of pure festivity.</br>BACCHUS shall his purple vine</br>Round the myrtle-tree entwine;</br>And VENUS too, with lovely mien,</br>Ever sportive, yet  serene,</br>Shall o'er the meads enraptur'd rove;</br>While the playful God of Love,</br>Rose-cheek'd Cherub, leads the way,</br>Blithsome as the blushing day;</br>While sober TEMP'RANCE chaste and mild</br>Sweetly carols wood-notes wild,</br>In russet garment, staid and free,</br>Chaunting songs of jollity!

HEALTH, to thee my lyre I string,</br>To thee my votive off'ring bring!</br>But where, Enchantress, dost thou dwell?</br>Secluded in some lonely cell,</br>Where from rural scenes remote</br>Is heard the hooting screetch-owl's note?</br>Or on some promontory's height</br>Impervious to the traveller's sight,</br>'Midst endless frosts and drifting snows,</br>Where Eurus stern impetuous blows?</br>Or dost thou seek the buxom vale,</br>Or in the spicy bow'r regale,</br>Or on beds of roses play,</br>List'ning to the love-fraught lay?</br>Oh!  Let me to thy mansion speed</br>O'er the green enamell'd mead;</br>To some far cave by moss o'ergrown,</br>Emboss'd with many a lustrous stone;</br>Where the ivy  crept around</br>The rugged sides by Time imbrown'd;</br>Far imbower'd in the glen,</br>Where the red-breast and the wren</br>Build their little nests, and sing</br>Carols to the jocund Spring,</br>While the Zephyr's silken sail</br>Fans the lillies of the vale:</br>There retired, let me be</br>With the courteous Muse and thee;</br>Hold dalliance with the Queen of Song,</br>Whose aid inspires the vocal throng.</br>Gladly then I'd strike the wire,</br>Sing of bliss and chaste desire,</br>Weave the wreath to bind my hair,</br>And drink the fragrance of the air.</br>So should my vagrant fancy stray,</br>Amidst the honey'd sweets of May,</br>Thro' waving woods and gay alcove,</br>Where music breathes the sound of love.</br>Oft let me seek at early dawn,</br>With mind compos'd, the dewy lawn;</br>Hear the blackbird in the bush,</br>And the sweetly thrilling thrush:</br>Let every prospect glad my sight</br>While I scale the steep rock's height,</br>Whose brow o'erhangs the breaking wave</br>Where blue Tritons love to lave,</br>Where Nereids from their coral cells</br>Sound aloud their twisted shells.</br>And when Eve, with drowsy eye,</br>Robes in grey the azure sky,</br>Let me roam with footsteps slow,</br>While the worm, with sheeny glow,</br>Illumes the torn-entangled hedge,</br>Peering through the side-way sedge,</br>Let me in the lonely hour</br>Seek some tott'ring ivy'd tow'r,</br>Or walk some abbey's aisles among,</br>"Where shiv'ring ghosts from charnels throng;"</br>Where the dark-mop'd owl complains,</br>While the bat close skims the plains,</br>With his leathern wings outspread,</br>As the Moon begins to shed</br>Her silv'ry lustre o'er the grove,</br>Where Contemplation joys to rove,</br>As slow he winds his sober pace,</br>With steady step and museful face.</br>Let me hasten to the note</br>Of the wailing songster's throat,</br>Who, sadly pining on her thorn,</br>Thrills in plaintive cadence, lorn,</br>To her idol flow'r, the Rose,</br>Which beneath mellifluous blows.</br>So long the forest's charms I'd sing,</br>Of leafy trees and endless spring;</br>Of flow'rets of enliv'ning dye,</br>The teeming Earth's embroidery;</br>Of whistling birds, of crystal fountains,</br>Rugged rocks and cloud-capt mountains;</br>But more of her, whose florid face,</br>Buxom air, and winning grace,</br>Claims the song and sounding lyre,</br>And the Poet's fervent fire;</br>All the eloquence we know;—</br>For want of HEALTH, what's life below?</br>Doom'd in a wretched state to mourn,</br>Bereft of peace, with mind forlorn,</br>We linger — 'till the winged dart</br>Vindictive strikes us to the heart,</br>And meet the turf-bound bed of clay,</br>Of mortals' woes the sure allay!</br>Then HEATH, enthusiastic maid,</br>O grant for once thy balmy aid,</br>And o'er my cheeks diffuse the flush,</br>The vermeil glow and living blush;</br>So long may'st thou my breast inspire,</br>Goddess of supreme desire!</br>And FANCY, and the Muse benign,</br>Teach me to weave the lofty rhyme!</br>Nor will I e'er, with lips prophane,</br>Insult the Muse with obscene strain,</br>But humbly wake the silver string,</br>Her sacred influence to sing.</br>And when Old Age, with wrinkled face,</br>Shall bid me quit Youth's gamesome chace,</br>May I reflect on pleasures past,</br>Nor grieve because they fled so fast!</br>And when the grisly tyrant, Death,</br>Demands, alas!  my fleeting breath,</br>May bright-ey'd HOPE, with soothing hand,</br>Point to the all-mysterious land,</br>And waft my soul to realms above,</br>Where all is calmness, truth, and love!</br>But while on lowly Earth I be,</br>HEALTH, let me ever live with thee!</br>
